creator: gregg@greggman.com
text:
If the user's HTTP_ACCEPT_LANGUAGE is set to en-us,ja;q=0.5 Japanese language 
appears even though English is listed first (as the preference of the user!)

creator: nd@perlig.de
text:
That is, what the standard defines. "en-us" is not equal "en". More: it denies
"en". Use "en" in your browser's preferences and all is fine.

Thanks for using Apache.

So then, given that IE defaults to EN-US not EN 70 or 80 percent of the pages 
being served by the apache are just getting lucky that they are serving up 
English?  If the server was from a Japanese company and they also made English 
pages most English seeking people would not get the English pages served.

On top of which there is a difference between EN-US and EN-GB.  For example, 
color vs colour, favor vs favour, theater vs theatre.

If EN-US is specified and not EN it seems like apache should serve EN not JP.
creator: gregg@greggman.com
slive@apache.org
text:
Don't complain to us; complain to Microsoft.  We are following the standards.

See:
http://ppewww.ph.gla.ac.uk/~flavell/www/lang-neg.html
http://httpd.apache.org/docs-2.0/content-negotiation.html

And the standards certainly don't prevent you from prefering a variant of
english.  The proper configuration in your case is something like

en-us,en;q=0.8,ja;q=0.5

creator: slive@apache.org
text:
And note also that in Apache 2, this problem will only occur for people
who have multiple languages in their accept-language header and have not
configured them properly.  So your example of the Japanese company is
not, in general, true.  See the "Language Negotiation Exceptions" section
of the content negotiation docs.
